respect.  As is, we have disrespectful teens, having disrespectful

top_comment.author: watcheem

comments.text:
Ironically, in Britain, calling someone 'sir' or 'ma'am' can actually be a 
little rude in some contexts, especially when you are trying to work with 
the person. We prefer to either leave out titles entirely or even call 
strangers mild terms of endearment like 'mate', or 'love', as in "Hey mate, 
anyone sitting here?". My mother had a Kentuckian (?) student call her 
"ma'am", and said that although she was slightly flattered, it also made 
her cringe. It throws up a barrier of formality that can make people 
uncomfortable if they're not used to it. In day to day life (at least 
outside of school), the only people who will call you "sir" are the police, 
doormen and security guards, and only if you're doing something they 
disapprove of.

comments.text:
It's just a different way. I can see he's a great dad, but even when 
working in a fancy hotel, I had great difficulty calling people 'sir' or 
'madam'. It felt like lying, or swearing at strangers. I also never felt 
that anyone was inherently better than me simply because of their seniority 
in the workplace. I have no deference to the boss simply because of his 
title, but I do respect his greater experience and the responsibilities of 
the position. If there is ever an implication that someone is innately 
inferior because of their position at work though, then we have a problem. 
I will always respect the person's merits, but never the title alone.

The reason for that is that I called my parents by their first names 
growing up, and I know that's unusual too. I suppose my British/Australian 
parents just have a much less reverent culture, and so long as I was 
respectful in deeds and attitude, it was not necessary to use titles for 
them. I won't say either way is better. So long as there is genuine respect 
for others and especially elders, I don't think it matters.
comments.author: tSp289

comments.text:
+Armathyx         1. "Your comments are ignorant and dishonest in how you 
clearly don't know much about evolution (you mentioned micro evolution, 
macro evolution, something about cosmological evolution... none of these 
are scientific terms, you are inventing things you don't know) and yet you 
judge the work of scientists as false."

1. It is your "opinion" that I do not know much about evolution. I however 
disagree with your "opinion". I believe I know a very decent amount about 
the "belief" or "theory" of "evolution".

Here are just some "beliefs" that I know to come from the "beliefs" of 
Macro-Evolution (A.) and Cosmic Evolution (B.).

A.  Most "evolutionists" "believe" (or again at least teach) that humans 
"evolved" from other living things through millions of years. They 
"believe" we evolved from Starfish, Sea sponges, etc...
   They "believe" about 30 million years ago (dates vary and change 
constantly) larger primates such as monkeys and apes evolved into humans. 
This "belief" of "evolution" is not limited to humans. This is all included 
in Macro-Evolution.

Sources: (Discover Magazine November 2004), (Holt Earth Science, 1989, pg 
294) 

No one has ever experienced Marco-Evolution. It takes "belief".

B.   Most "evolutionist" "believe" (or at least have been teaching young 
students) in the "Big Bang Theory" (or whatever other starting "spark" they 
"believe") happened around 20-22 Billion years ago (date varies and changes 
constantly, also note some also "believe"/teach that the universe is a 
closed universe, which leads to another slightly different "belief" as to 
what happens). Most believe that all the matter in the universe was either 
condensed into a very hot, very small dot, or that all the matter came from 
nothing at all and In a quote from one of the leading scientific magazines 
one of our foremost theoretical physicists and cosmologists he said:“The 
observable universe could have evolved from an infinitesimal region. It’s 
then tempting to go one step further and speculate that the entire universe 
evolved from literally nothing".). Either way, when this dot (or nothing) 
exploded they "believe" it somehow created "time" "space" and "matter". 
This is all included in Cosmic Evolution.

    A person can talk about their "belief" that reptiles evolved into birds 
all day long, but where did the reptile come from? The answer for most is 
the "belief" of Organic Evolution. How life came from something that wasn't 
living. Well then how did a rock, or soup mixture from an ocean turn into a 
living thing. Where did that rock come from? It all leads back to the 
"belief" of "Cosmic Evolution"

Sources from school text books:(Prentice Hall Earth Science, 1999 pg.63), 
(Prentice Hall Earth Science, 1999 pg.63 and Prentice Hall General Science, 
1992 pg.61), and (HBJ General Science, 1989, pg 362).

   Cosmic Evolution has never been observed or experienced. It is not 
science.
It is however needed to occur for certain parts of "Evolution" to happen.
Some questions one might ask. 
What made the Big Bang happen (what caused it to explode)? 
What was before this dot (or nothingness, if there really was nothing then 
what about the 1st law of thermodynamics which says that matter and energy 
cannot be destroyed or created)? 
Where did or when did the laws even form (and do they change)?
What caused this dot to hold together (what kept it condensed)? 
What originally caused it to come together? 
Where did the matter and energy come from?

 Any person can ask me questions about my "faith" in God. Rightfully I can 
also question their "belief" in evolution.

  Many "believe" that the universe is a closed universe and that we keep 
getting squished and then exploded over and over.

 Well then if someone tells me that their "belief" is that everything 
always existed, (and that that is how we got here),  I can point to my 
"belief" that my God always existed (and that him creating us is how we got 
here). 

Neither one can be experienced today.
 
     Yes I did mention those terms (micro,macro, etc) in my last post 
because they are what make up the different meanings of "evolution".  When 
someone says "evolution" they could be referring to any on of them.

  You state they (micro, macro, etc...) are not "scientific" "terms". I 
would then ask what "your" "definition" for "scientific terms" in your 
statement means? What words do "you" consider to be "scientific terms". For 
instance "Macro-evolution" has it's own definition in the dictionary, and 
so does "Micro-Evolution". I fail to see how I invented something that is 
already in the dictionary. The other words are also commonly known and 
talked about by both evolutionists, and creationists alike.
Here are the definitions from one dictionary for Macro and Micro-evolution.

"Mac·ro·ev·o·lu·tion makro-ev?'lo?oSH?n,?ev?/
Noun-BIOLOGY
Major "Evolutionary" (developmental) change. The term applies mainly to the 
evolution of whole taxonomic groups over long periods of time."

Mi·cro·ev·o·lu·tion?mikro-ev?'lo?oSH?n,?ev?/
Noun-BIOLOGY
Evolutionary (developmental) change within a species or small group of 
organisms, especially over a short period.

 You also state that I judge the work of scientists as false. Where is this 
"work" from these scientists? I am assuming you are saying that they have 
experienced evidence of evolution.

 How can one judge something that does not exist? There is nothing to 
judge, but the unproved "belief" of evolution, and I don't think that it is 
a very good "belief" at all.

2. You also show narrow mindedness when you assume that a scientist's job 
is to simply look at a fossil and declare what it is, that's a really 
stupid assumption and you know it. I can smell the bad faith 10km away.

2.Can you please show me where I stated this assumption, or point out what 
led you to believe that I assumed this? I don't believe I ever did. I did 
bring fossils up, but not in the context that you are saying I did.


3. "And I mean, your overwhelming use of semantics proves the rest of your 
intellectual dishonesty..."

3. Again don't see how I am to talk with you without using the meaning of 
words, sentence, phrases, and text. I also fail to see how I could 
understand what you are stating unless you were using the meaning or words, 
sentences, phrases, and text behind what you post.

 The meaning of words and their definitions are important. If definitions 
and meanings did not exist for words, then words would be meaningless.

It appears like you are saying that because I am using the meaning of 
words, sentences, phrases, and text to communicate with you it somehow 
shows "intellectual dishonesty", but if your own words are applied to you 
then you would be showing the same.

4. "...it's not like you're bringing up maths to disprove evolution, you're 
just playing these word games, thinking I'm stupid enough to be convinced 
by your mediocre rhetoric, trying to explain that evolution isn't 
scientific."

4.How can one bring up maths to disprove something that does not exist?

Here is a definition of mathematics from the dictionary.

MATHEMATICS-The science of quantity; the science which treats of magnitude 
and number, or of whatever can be measured or numbered. 

So mathematics is the science of quantity, science is knowledge, and 
knowledge is a clear and certain perception of that which exists, or of 
truth and fact.

 I can have a knowledge of two apples and therefore quantify (or number) 
them. They exist.
 One can not quantify something that does not exist though.

Your implying that I should use mathematics, which requires something that 
exists, to disprove Evolution, which does not exist and has never been 
observed), and thereby prove that it is something that can't be perceived 
so as to be called science. I don't need to disprove that one can't 
perceive something that does not exist.

Evolution is not science.

5. "To me, anyone who delves into semantics in a discussion immediately 
loses credibility, because it's the lowest thing one can resort to, any kid 
can start playing stupid word games just to stall the discussion and avoid 
admitting they are wrong. In your case, not only you go into semantics, but 
even there you're still wrong about it."

5. Again I fail to see how someone using words and their proper definition 
loses credibility. Nor do I see how it is the lowest thing that someone can 
resort to.

It seems that you "believe" that when one starts using a word and 
definition they are "playing stupid word games". It also seems that you 
"think" the fact that they do this means that they are stalling instead of 
admitting they are wrong.

This "belief" would apply to yourself then as well.

You can "believe" I am wrong whether I am wrong or right. 

However you will not tell me the living empirical (experienced) evidence of 
evolution (the one you are referencing besides Micro evolution) that you 
have to demonstrate how it can be personally experienced so that it could 
rightfully be called science.

6. "Look at how you say "evolution is just a theory". A Theory in science 
is NOT a hypothesis. It's a full fledged model that has the hypothesis, the 
observations and conclusions to establish itself as part of reality, just 
like the theory of gravity. Please do yourself a favor and go to school."

6. If evolution is a fact then why is Darwin quoted as saying "...If my 
theory be true..." 

HYPOTHESIS-is "A supposition; a proposition or principle which is supposed 
or taken for granted, in order to draw a conclusion or inference for proof 
of the point in question; something not proved,but assumed for the purpose 
of argument.".

A hypothesis is the position of something known not to be true or not 
proved.

If "evolution" has hypothesis then as a whole it is not true or not proved, 
then "evolution" (the parts that are not true or proved) cannot be 
considered science. 

7. "It's a full fledged model that has the hypothesis, the observations and 
conclusions to establish itself as part of reality, just like the theory of 
gravity. Please do yourself a favor and go to school.

7. You seem to again say evolution has been observed. I will again ask for 
you to give a living experienced observation of a reptile giving birth to a 
bird. Evolution is not a reality it cannot be experienced to be called 
science.

You seem to state that evolution has been established just like the theory 
of gravity. 

 Well I will at least mention before I go on that there are some people out 
there that would say that Evolution is not even a "theory" because it can 
not be experienced. They consider it like trying to explain how something 
happened that has never happened. It's certainly something to challenge 
ones understanding of the terms hypothesis, theory, and law.


Anyways for gravity (if one was not aware) there is what people consider to 
be the law of gravity, and then there are actually a couple different 
"theories" of gravity.
The law is what appears to happen.
The theory tries to explain why.
One thing to point out is that the theory explaining why it happens 
actually tries to explain something that actually happens.


A law does nothing more than tell you how something behaves. It does not 
tell you why it behaves the way it does.

The theory is what examines what happens and tells one why and how it 
happened. 

Don't think that a theory is immune to being proved wrong though. Theories 
are changed entirely or ditched all the time . They are not necessarily 
true. 

I actually fail to see what observable thing the "Theory of Evolution" is 
trying to explain. Seeing that "evolution" (not Micro) has no way to 
actually be personally experienced. 

   Hypothesis, Theory, and Law, these are terms that are argued about, and 
need to be properly defined, but I will be honest the words are defined 
very differently even among people who all "believe" in "evolution".

8. "I don't want to have a real debate because it's a waste of my time. 
There is nothing to debate about evolution, it's been discovered a hundred 
years ago. It's the reality of the world we live in. I already have a good 
understanding on how it works, and the science we use based on evolution 
works just fine. All I'm saying is that you should go and further your 
education, go watch channels like SciShow or something."

8. II don't see how it is possible for us to have a fake debate.

 You say evolution was discovered a hundred years ago, but still no one has 
live experienced evidence for this "belief".

Evolution is not the reality of the world we live in currently.

     If this "belief" of evolution is now being excepted as science purely 
based on the"belief" that it exists then the word science needs to be 
updated in the dictionary. Just realize that in doing so, I can also call 
the "belief" of creation a science as well. And anyone else with a "belief" 
can also slap the statement science onto their "belief"

    Watching more of people explain this "belief" of evolution will only 
tell me more about the "belief". It will not give me any personal 
experienced evidence so that I could know it happens.

 It all comes down to this again.

I currently admit what I "believe" is by "faith". 

You will not admit that your "belief" is a "belief", but yet you will not 
give the personally experienced evidence that you say you have for it to 
show that it is science.

Please provide it.

comments.text:
+Armathyx  1. "No I don't have to show you anything, prove to you anything, 
or even speak to you at all. I don't owe you my time. It's a courtesy from 
me to answer you, not an obligation."
1.I agree with you. I also have these same rights to choose whether or not 
I talk to someone as well. 
2."I started writing a reply, but seeing how dishonest and ignorant your 
comments were, it's a waste of time trying to talk to you, you're not gonna 
come out of this discussion like "aha, I learned something new today!"."
2. You again are free to "believe" and state that my comments are dishonest 
and ignorant. I am then also free to ask you how they are dishonest and 
ignorant. How are they? 
The whole point of a debate is to argue or discuss your "beliefs" or 
"point" with another person or group of people. Whether or not either side 
comes away learning something is their own personal matter. 
Also just because either side learns something from the debate does not 
mean that their "beliefs" or "points" are wrong or right.
In a debate one person could point out to the other that some grass appears 
green. If the other person had never observed that grass could appear 
green, then he just learned something. The fact that he learned something 
during the debate doesn't necessarily mean that the point he is arguing is 
wrong. He could have been arguing that caterpillars turn into butterflies 
by showing a video of it happening. While the video was playing someone 
yelled out "Wow that grass is a beautiful green!", and right there he 
learned that some grass can appear green. It doesn't void his "point" that 
caterpillars turn into butterflies though.
However I will say that one can not learn something that is not presented.
Which an experienced live example of evolution taking place has not been 
presented. 
3. "When you described what you think the scientific work is, you proved 
your bad faith on this matter, you're intentionally narrow minded and are 
belittling the work of the scientific community as if you were some rocket 
scientist."
3. This again I see would come back then to the defining of the word 
science. If you have another word other then science that you are trying to 
address please bring it up. The word science I "believe" to be adequately 
defined by the dictionary's definition. 
One can say that the dictionary's definition of a word is narrow minded, 
that is their opinion, but to say that a person is narrow minded for 
quoting and using the definition of a word in the dictionary (for the 
purpose of their argument) seems wrong.
If the word science was defined differently then what it is today (and 
differently then it has been defined in the past), then sure maybe 
evolution would possibly be able to be called science.
That is not the case though (that the word science means something 
different).
So with that I fail to see how I have belittled the scientific community 
using the very definition of science that they seem to be using. No one 
needs a degree to be called a scientist. Anyone, anywhere, can be a 
scientist. One does not have to believe in evolution or creation to be a 
scientist. One also is not a scientist because they believe in creation or 
evolution.  
4. "If you want to know and understand evolution, don't ask me to explain 
it to you. There are tons of people who have written books for you to learn 
it, and there's educational videos on Youtube for you to watch for free. 
You can also attend some of the seminars at universities for free. Do 
yourself a favor and further your education. See ya."?
4.Again to know something it must exist. You it seems are stating that 
evolution is science, therefore evolution must exist and a living happening 
of it should be able to be experienced personally by a person. However it 
cannot be, therefore evolution is not science but only a theory, hence the 
"Theory of Evolution".
You stated that you have empirical (experienced) evidence of it happening. 
Naturally I would want to know, because I have not found any anywhere else 
that I have looked. I stated the different forms of evolution because they 
would all need to be able to be experienced in order for evolution to be 
called science. 
One would need to be able to experience the origin of time matter and space 
from nothing in the "Big Bang".
One would need to be able to experience chemical evolution, all elements 
"evolving" from hydrogen.
One would need to be able to experience Stellar and planetary evolution, 
seeing stars and planets form from gas clouds.
One would need to experience Organic Evolution life beginning from 
inanimate matter.
One would need to be able to experience Macro Evolution, animals and plants 
changing from one type into another. An ape giving birth to a human.
I do not know of any of these that one can experience and call them 
science. One can say that they need "time" (billions and billions of years) 
to occur, but then that again means that it is a "belief" or "theory" and 
not science.
Again you have stated that you have empirical (experienced) evidence of 
evolution. I would like to see it.
 It is like two different kinds of teachers conversing with one student.
If the student comes to one of the teachers saying they have tried with all 
their means to figure a problem out, and that teacher tells them that they 
have the answer (meaning the teacher has the answer), but not to ask them 
how to solve it because they won't give them the answer, what else is that 
student to do? The student has already done everything in their power to 
figure it out. The teacher is claiming to know the answer, but will not 
show it to prove that they have it. 
The teacher can say "Go ask him.", or "Go over their.", but if the answer 
isn't really there the student will never find it.
The same student then goes to the other teacher and ask them for the 
answer. That teacher tells them they don't have the answer, but that they 
do have some "theories" as to what the answer is, and that they would be 
willing to share them with them.
I claim that what I am saying is a "belief" not "science". I can also point 
to many people who can talk and share about their "belief" or "theory". 
However even they cannot give a person empirical evidence that their 
"theory" is no longer a "theory" and has now become "science".
The difference between you and I at the moment is that you are saying you 
have the "answer" but will not show it.
I am saying that I don't have the answer, but I do have some "theories", 
and would be glad to share.
With that I would suggest Kent Hovind as a creationist with some "theories" 
or "ideas" to consider as to how God created.
One can also look up his videos on you-tube for free. A good one to start 
at would be Kent Hovind The Age of The Earth.
Lastly again the main point is there is a difference between "science" and 
"theories".
One can further their understanding of the "beliefs" and  "theories" of 
evolution and creation their whole life. The process of furthering that 
understanding however does not make evolution or creation become "science".
comments.author: CAR DEC

scientist. One also is not a scientist because they believe in creation or 
evolution.  
4. "If you want to know and understand evolution, don't ask me to explain 
it to you. There are tons of people who have written books for you to learn 
it, and there's educational videos on Youtube for you to watch for free. 
You can also attend some of the seminars at universities for free. Do 
yourself a favor and further your education. See ya."?
4.Again to know something it must exist. You it seems are stating that 
evolution is science, therefore evolution must exist and a living happening 
of it should be able to be experienced personally by a person. However it 
cannot be, therefore evolution is not science but only a theory, hence the 
"Theory of Evolution".
You stated that you have empirical (experienced) evidence of it happening. 
Naturally I would want to know, because I have not found any anywhere else 
that I have looked. I stated the different forms of evolution because they 
would all need to be able to be experienced in order for evolution to be 
called science. 
One would need to be able to experience the origin of time matter and space 
from nothing in the "Big Bang".
One would need to be able to experience chemical evolution, all elements 
"evolving" from hydrogen.
One would need to be able to experience Stellar and planetary evolution, 
seeing stars and planets form from gas clouds.
One would need to experience Organic Evolution life beginning 
from inanimate matter.
One would need to be able to experience Macro Evolution, animals and plants 
changing from one type into another. An ape giving birth to a human.
I do not know of any of these that one can experience and call them 
science. One can say that they need "time" (billions and billions of years) 
to occur, but then that again means that it is a "belief" or "theory" and 
not science.
Again you have stated that you have empirical (experienced) evidence of 
evolution. I would like to see it.
 It is like two different kinds of teachers conversing with one student.
If the student comes to one of the teachers saying they have tried with all 
their means to figure a problem out, and that teacher tells them that they 
have the answer (meaning the teacher has the answer), but not to ask them 
how to solve it because they won't give them the answer, what else is that 
student to do? The student has already done everything in their power to 
figure it out. The teacher is claiming to know the answer, but will not 
show it to prove that they have it. 
The teacher can say "Go ask him.", or "Go over their.", but if the answer 
isn't really there the student will never find it.
The same student then goes to the other teacher and ask them for the 
answer. That teacher tells them they don't have the answer, but that they 
do have some "theories" as to what the answer is, and that they would be 
willing to share them with them.
I claim that what I am saying is a "belief" not "science". I can also point 
to many people who can talk and share about their "belief" or "theory". 
However even they cannot give a person empirical evidence that their 
"theory" is no longer a "theory" and has now become "science".
The difference between you and I at the moment is that you are saying you 
have the "answer" but will not show it.
I am saying that I don't have the answer, but I do have some "theories", 
and would be glad to share.
With that I would suggest Kent Hovind as a creationist with some "theories" 
or "ideas" to consider as to how God created.
One can also look up his videos on you-tube for free. A good one to start 
at would be Kent Hovind The Age of The Earth.
Lastly again the main point is there is a difference between "science" and 
"theories".
One can further their understanding of the "beliefs" and  "theories" of 
evolution and creation their whole life. The process of furthering that 
understanding however does not make evolution or creation become "science".

comments.text:
1."Who are you to say they don't happen? There's as much empirical evidence 
to evolution as there is evidence to a crime scene where the murderer left 
handprints and personal items scattered all over the place."

1.You again state that there is empirical (experienced) evidence for 
evolution. 
 I have asked for you to show me a living example of it happening today. If 
there is no living example of it happening today then it cannot be 
experienced to be called science. It is just a "theory". 
You say there is as much empirical evidence for evolution as there is to a 
crime scene.
 The crime of murder without the murderer being known gets a little more 
complicated. There can be thousands of footprints and fingerprints in the 
room of the crime, but one has to find the right ones that were responsible 
for the murder. One also then needs to find the person responsible for 
making those footprints and fingerprints. One can't just point to all 1,000 
and say "See, this person was murdered by these 1,000 fingerprints and 
footprints".The fingerprints and footprints are not what murdered the 
victim. Again one would have to find the person who made the fingerprints 
and footprints before bringing the "suspect" to trial.

One cannot look at a fossil and say that it is a missing link for a reptile 
turning into a bird and call it science. You don't know if that fossil had 
any offspring. You don't know if the fossil's parents didn't already have 
the wings.
It's like saying that the footprint is the thing responsible for the murder.
No, bring me the person who is responsible for the footprint and prove to 
me how they did the murder.

 Show me the living experience of your fossil turning into another animal. 
Something that is real usually makes a footprint. You show the footprint, 
but can't show the thing that made it. There is no case to be made.
You are trying to say what made the footprint without actually seeing for 
yourself what made it.
 I will not deny that you can "believe" or "speculate" that your footprint 
was left by the process of evolution. It is another thing to say though 
that you have anything more than that footprint. 
Not only that, but as I have stated before, the creationist looks at that 
same footprint and makes their own "speculations" and "beliefs" about what 
made it as well. Somebody is wrong and somebody is right, or both are 
wrong. Neither however has personal empirical evidence for their "belief". 
If they did then it would not be called a theory.

Destin's "about" page (on February 23, 2015) says this "I explore the world 
using science. That's pretty much all there is to it..."

Now he is showing us science in his balloon experiment. How? I can go and 
do what he is doing and experience it for myself. So Destin can say he has 
empirical evidence for this balloon experiment. I can also go do this 
balloon experiment and have empirical evidence for myself that it can be 
done.

Now if Destin had posted a video not showing anything but him saying "Look 
here is science!", and then went on to say  "I believe that if you drive 
forward in your car with a balloon attached to the floor of the car it will 
turn into 8 solid gold bars!" 
That would not be science! No one can do this experiment and get that 
result. 
Now Destin could "believe" this as much as he wanted. He could look for 
proof of it's happening his whole life. However it does not change the fact 
that it hasn't happened to be witnessed, and that it cannot be experienced 
by others to be called science. Destin himself wouldn't even have had the 
experience to tell so that others could put their "faith" in what he saw.
You ask who am I to say it does not happen (in regards to evolution). I am 
a human being, therefore I am able to utilize science. I cannot however 
call something science that is not science. Science has a definition. 
Science has a meaning. If you are to call something science it must fall 
into science's definition.
Which leads me into your next statements about word meanings and semantics.
2."Also, there is no such thing as micro and macro evolution, those terms 
are not scientific.
The rest of your post is pure semantics. It really is, you wrote a huge 
wall of text of semantics, with a few baseless claims. It's all irrelevant. 
I'm not interested in adressing any of this."
2. Well I don't agree with you as far as Marco-evolution and 
Mirco-Evolution not having value (as far as a word or phrase having meaning 
goes). 
What you said about Macro-Evolution alone does hold some truth, although 
not in the way you were stating it. Macro-Evolution cannot be called 
science. It cannot be experienced. It therefore is a "Theory" or 
speculation.
You say what I wrote is semantics. SEMANTICS- is the meaning of a word, 
phrase, sentence, or text.
So I fail to understand how anyone is supposed to communicate with another 
person if neither can use words, phrases, sentences, or texts that have a 
meaning or a definite definition. I have been trying not to say crucial 
words without defining them, because then the interpretation is left open 
to speculation.
Without a definition of a word we could be talking about two different 
subjects.
If one does not believe the meaning of words are important then why was a 
dictionary ever made?
I don't "believe" I am being unreasonable with the words I am using.
I am not defining a word like cheeseburger and saying that it is an insect 
that flies around a barn.
You are free to address anything you like. 
3. "What I'm interested in seeing, however, is you proving your points 
through mathematics or direct, empirical evidence. If you can't provide 
that, too bad for you, you have no credibility."﻿
3.I have already told you. I cannot give you empirical evidence that God 
created. I was not there to perceive and experience it.
What I "believe" you are failing to see is that you also cannot give a 
living example of empirical evidence that evolution happens.
I am willing to say that I cannot give you what you are asking for. You 
seem to not be willing to say that you cannot give me what I am asking you 
for.
It is like two people each "believing" they personally own a dog, but each 
not having any personal memory or experience with their own dog. They each 
personally don't know where there dog is. They are each asking to see the 
other's dog as proof that the other actually owns a dog. The one admits 
that although he "believes" he has a dog, he does not actually have the dog 
to show. The other insists that he too has a dog, but is not willing to 
admit that he doesn't really have his dog to show the other. 
If you have your dog please show him.
I have asked for a living example of a reptile turning into a bird.
You have stated that you have thousands of examples of empirical evidence 
for evolution. 
You still have not provided any though.
So you can say I have no credibility, but if you were held to your own 
words, neither do you.
Please tell me what breed of dog I can go buy, male and female, and then 
breed them too get a bird? Please tell me what experiment I can do to get 
living experienced evidence that evolution happens.
Destin can show me that his balloon experiment is science. I can go do his 
experiment and get the same results as him for myself.  
Please show me how I can experience a live example of evolution so that I 
can experience it and consider it to see if it can be called science.

comments.text:
Interesting... You say "Both Armathyx and I can point to thousands on 
thousands of incidents proving evolution." 
Please tell about these incidents and tell about how they can be or have 
been experienced by somebody..
However before you do, I would like to know what evolution you are 
referring to.

Cosmic evolution: the origin of time, space, and matter from nothing in the 
“big bang”
Chemical evolution: all elements “evolved” from hydrogen
Stellar evolution: stars and planets formed from gas clouds
Organic evolution: life begins from inanimate matter
Macro-evolution: animals and plants change from one type into another
or
Micro-evolution: variations form within the “kind”?
People can experience Micro-evolution. It happens, but these others do not 
happen and cannot be empirical (experienced) evidence.

 I am curious to see your incidents of evolution. 

Your statements
1."[referencing the enormous body of knowledge of information around 
evolution]"

1. I still don't know of any enormous body of knowledge of information 
around evolution. I can't perceive something that does not exist.

2."It is just knowledge, the values used in discerning the information are 
the point of difference."
2. Knowledge- means "A clear and certain perception of that which exists, 
or of truth and fact; the perception of the connection and agreement, or 
disagreement and repugnancy of our ideas.
We can have no knowledge of that which does not exist."
You say that evolution is just knowledge. I would disagree to that. 
Knowledge is a perception of that which exists. It is a truth or fact.
SCIENCE- is "In a general sense, knowledge, or certain knowledge; the 
comprehension or understanding of truth or facts by the mind."
Science only deals with things that exist. It only deals with facts.
FACT- is "Any thing done, or that comes to pass; an act; a deed; an effect 
produced or achieved; an event. Witnesses are introduced into court to 
prove a fact." Those witnesses have to have experienced the fact. It's not 
a fact unless it has been experienced by the individual.
Evolution is not a fact. It is a belief, theory, or speculation. That is 
why it is called the Theory of Evolution. Evolution itself is not science. 
In order for it to be science it must be able to be observed and 
experienced personally by an individual.
I have never experienced seeing a living dog give birth to an eagle. 
I would dare to say neither has anyone else.
That is why it is a Theory.
Both an evolutionist and a creationist can look at the same fossils and 
come up with different theories of how they got there. Neither of their 
theories have been experienced though. Neither of their theories are for 
sure facts.
They can "believe" them, but they have not experienced them.

Also you use the word values.
In order for something to have value it must have worth. It must exist.
VALUE- means "Worth; that property or those properties of a thing which 
render it useful or estimable; or the degree of that property or of such 
properties. The real value of a thing is its utility, its power or capacity 
of procuring or producing good. Hence the real or intrinsic value of iron, 
is far greater than that of gold. But there is, in many things, an 
estimated value, depending on opinion or fashion, such as the value of 
precious stones. The value of land depends on its fertility, or on its 
vicinity to a market, or on both."

3."Where you have not evolved past an early stage of value development, 
others have.
Developing a different altitude with wider perspective.
3. I again would find it interesting to know your definition of "evolved" 
here. I am assuming that the word here you are using it to state 
advancement. It would make this even more interesting if you were saying 
that I have not evolved as in Macro-Evolution.
As far as I know you and I are still both human. So again I am assuming you 
are referring to advancement.
Which I would not agree that your "belief" is an advancement. Nor do I 
think that it is right that you seemingly say that one who doesn't 
"believe" the way you do has not "evolved?" past an early stage of 
development.
You say these people who have passed this early stage of development have 
developed a different altitude with wider perspectives.

Now I do agree that certain "beliefs" will change a persons attitude, but 
that doesn't mean that the "belief" is right. Somebody could have a belief 
that killing all the animals in the world was his duty. This would 
certainly change his attitude towards people's pets, and broaden his 
perspective so that he would ignore the fact that other people may like 
their pet, and he would start shooting every animal he saw.
Hitler had a "belief" that people of certain qualities should be 
eliminated. It certainly affected his attitude and perspective.
4."All that is needed is knowledge, context and discernment. However sadly 
 these values are opaque to you, unseen and literally unknowable.
4. Again knowledge is a clear perception of that which exists. Values can't 
be opaque to a person unless those values are based on something that 
exists. So how can something that does not exist be put into context or 
discerned? How can something that does not exist even have worth? To my 
knowledge it can't.
You say that these values (which truth be told I do not see... because they 
are not there) are unseen to me (I agree I can't see something that does 
not exist), and literally unknowable (yes you can not perceive something 
that is not there).
5. "Why unknowable? 
Because you like many with unevolved value systems; are simply stuck on an 
earlier tier of human development.*"
5. So it seems that someone who does not "believe" or at least "think" the 
same as you is automatically stuck on an earlier tier of human development. 
That is fine to "believe" within your "belief".
6."This level of development has nothing to do with intelligence and worth, 
just the personal evolution of values, each of us grow - some not so much, 
that is all."
6. I would disagree completely with the statement that it has nothing to do 
with intelligence and worth. I could theorize that several people with this 
"belief" system "COULD" see others that don't believe the same as 
worthless. You have already stated that I am stuck in an earlier tier of 
human development and that I might not grow much at all. So if someone with 
your belief system knows that I might not "grow much at all" why not just 
get rid of me? I am not trying to say that you believe this way. I am 
trying to state I see some possible dangers in this approach (at least for 
people like me I guess).
Also it does not make sense that you say this development has nothing to do 
with worth.
If your "belief" is so much better then someone who does not "believe" then 
they would not show as much worth.
A baby and a man both have worth.
However if you narrow the context of worth down just to whether or not they 
can work and plow land. Then the man has more worth because he can and the 
baby cannot.
So I personally think that your "belief" does set worth to people at least 
in certain contexts.
7. "Flipping the question:
How can you know God exists and he created the earth?
Faith is just not enough in this era of technology, and vast human 
knowledge... 
Still in all probability, your answer - going on earlier comments is;
'belief' or faith a hope God both exists and created life on earth.  
Say that aloud, hear the words and meaning. Feel what that set of language 
really indicates.
Because I have seen 4 year olds with a similar belief in Santa, no one 
could tell them he wasn't real either!" 
7. Yes you are right I "believe" have "faith" and "hope" in God.
I will point out that one who "believes" in the "theory" of evolution is 
doing the same thing. They are believing something. So if faith is not 
enough in this era of technology, and vast human knowledge then those that 
"believe" in evolution are having the same faith you say is not enough.
I understand what you are saying about Santa. However if you are going to 
use it in that context your "belief" also applies.

One could ask the child to prove to another that Santa exists. They could 
point to the man dressed as Santa in the mall. Now the Santa in the mall is 
lying, but that is a lie that is effecting the child is it not? The child 
sees this lie and believes it.
So moving on, one could show the child that the Santa is just a man by 
pulling his beard off. That doesn't mean the four year old will stop 
believing. However that four year old will convince no one until Santa can 
be shown.
Same with Evolution.
Same with God creating the world.
A creationist can look at the same fossils a evolutionist looks at and come 
up with a different theory than him. The evolutionist can do the same.
However one thing that is upsetting is that in evolution many things get 
put in (I am not saying on purpose) that are later found to be a fraud or a 
hoax. These things remain in children's text books for a long time before 
they are taken out. 

I personally don't like the idea of Santa to begin with because parents are 
originally knowingly lying to their children. However if the parents truly 
believed in Santa and found out he was fake and then continued to try and 
convince their children he was real that would be very wrong ( and yet I 
suppose this is what is happening seeing that the parents themselves when 
younger were lied to as well, found the lie out, but then still passed it 
along).
The difference is that Santa is looked at as something fun to lie to the 
children about (not saying it's right). Does that mean other beliefs that 
adults believe should get these same liberties of lying?
8. Lastly "The body of evolution exists, it is your choice to have belief 
in it or not. That is point of difference - no faith or hope is required. 
Both Armathyx and I can point to thousands on thousands of incidents 
proving evolution. Where is your evidence?"
8. I disagree with you that you don't need "faith" to "believe" evolution 
as I have stated previously.
FAITH- is 1. "Belief; the assent of the mind to the truth of what is 
declared by another, resting on his authority and veracity, without other 
evidence; the judgment that what another states or testifies is the truth. 
I have strong faith or no faith in the testimony of a witness, or in what a 
historian narrates."
Unless you can say you yourself have experienced a living example of 
evolution happening (a fish turning into a bird) you are "believing" 
another person's words or statements as you yourself have not experienced 
it. A person can read and believe Darwin's book, but even Darwin himself 
did not personally experience a live fish giving birth to a bird. So that 
person is taking on another person's "belief".
And I do not know of any person throughout human history who has ever 
claimed that they experienced macro-evolution and then went and testified 
about it so that others could have "faith" in what he said. Because even if 
there had been such a person, his word of mouth could only give somebody 
the choice to put faith in what they said, unless they themselves too could 
experience macro-evolution taking place.
To my knowledge today there is still only the theory that it even takes 
place.
You ask where my evidence is. We need to determine what evidence is though.
EVIDENCE- is "That which elucidates and enables the mind to see truth; 
proof arising from our own perceptions by the senses, or from the testimony 
of others, or from inductions of reason."
I would bring up the testimony of others. 
I would bring up the writings of the people who wrote the old-testament. 
They wrote about how God created. They told about how Christ would come, 
and what he would do.
I would then point to the writers (Many who were eye witnesses of Jesus) of 
the new-testament, how the old-testament prophecies were fulfilled, how 
they wrote about how Jesus came and died for our sins according to the 
scriptures, he was buried, and that he rose again on the third day 
according to the scriptures. 
These are people giving an account of what they experienced. Now I was not 
there. So I put my "faith" in what they said. There are a lot of 
testimonies from these people. I also see in my life certain things that 
they talked about happen. It is my "belief" that reason these things happen 
is because of the reasons they say they would happen.
I cannot give you empirical evidence of God creating the universe simply 
because I was not there.
Remember what evidence is though. It is proof arising from our perceptions 
by the senses, or from the testimony of others.
It is a convincing factor, but a person still has to make a choice on a 
matter.
There could be evidence on both sides for two opposing views. One is still 
most likely wrong and one is still most likely right.
Both the evolutionist and the creationist have what they believe to be 
evidence to support their "beliefs". They wouldn't however need evidence 
for either "belief" if it was something that could be experienced today. If 
it could be experienced today then it would be a fact and fall into being 
called science.

And it all comes back to just that, science is knowledge the comprehension 
of truth and facts. Knowledge is a clear perception of that which exists, 
or truth and fact.
If something has not been experienced as a fact by an individual it will 
always fall into the category of "belief" or "faith".

+Bill C "Explain that's it's all a natural phenomena and no big deal as 
they don't do anything and aren't useful. ... But I'd rather have them

There's your problem. You think some leprechaun story about rainbows makes

comments.text:
+Phynos You go right ahead and tell your kids that rainbows are nothing 
more than an optical and meteorological phenomenon that is caused by 
reflection and refraction of light in water droplets in Earth's atmosphere, 
resulting in a spectrum of light appearing in the sky. You can explain the

spreading of light into spectra colors that forms a half-circle when viewed 
on the ground, etc. Explain that's it's all a natural phenomena and no big

comments.text:
+RonJohn63 No, the speed of sound is faster in helium. The equation for the 
speed of sound in an ideal gas is c=(γkT/m)^0.5, where γ is the heat 
capacity ratio, k is the Boltzmann constant, T is the temperature and m is 
the particle mass.

Monoatomic gases like helium have a slightly lower heat capacity ratio than 
diatomic gases like nitrogen or oxygen, but helium has a much lower 
particle mass so it has a faster speed of sound. This is because the 
particles move faster for the same temperature.

Iron and water are (at room temperature) solids and liquids respectively, 
so they behave under different rules. Heat them up until they evaporate and 
at the same temperature sound will travel faster through helium.

In terms of a vaccum, you are mixing up speed and ease of travel.
comments.author: IamGrimalkin

comments.text:
/how they travel faster through helium/

Or not.

Think about it: if they traveled faster through a medium less-dense than 
air, then sound would travel super-fast in a vacuum, since that's a *lot* 
less dense than air.

But obviously it doesn't.

Since sound is a pressure wave, it needs something to propagate through. 
 That's why it travels 4x faster in water, and 15x faster in iron.

comments.text:
+Tomek Samcik That would be reading a bit too much into the equivalence 
principle.

The idea is in fact a lot humbler. It just says that if you're in a locked 
room and you feel gravity you can't say if you're in an accelerating 
spaceship or on the surface of the Earth. That's all. That's what people 
mean when they say that there's a local equivalence between these frames.

The Earth, or the space around it, aren't "accelerating" in all directions 
at once or anything like that. That doesn't even make sense. The space is 
just curved in such a way that it's equivalent, locally, to a frame that's 
experiencing a constant acceleration.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+JourneyTotheTruthandTotalRandomness Earth can't be accelerating in all

accelerating towards it's center, not sure if it makes any sense in terms

comments.author: Tomek Samcik

comments.text:
+JourneyTotheTruthandTotalRandomness Newtons second law:
Force = mass x acceleration.

On Earth that acceleration is 9.81m/s^2, which is the rate of acceleration 
you will experience if you jump out a plane. When you are walking around on 
the ground, gravity doesn't just switch off. It's still holding you on the 
ground.

"If gravity is the same as acceleration then how does that work with a 
spherical object like the earth.  That would mean the earth would have to 
be accelerating in all directions at once which I'm pretty sure isn't 
happening."

It is. The earth is accelerating radially inwards in all directions. That 
9.81 figure  I just mentioned is only on the earth's surface. Gravity 
actually gets stronger the closer you get to the centre of the Earth, which 
is why you weigh slightly less on the equator than you do on the North Pole.

"But inertia does not need gravity to work hence why we have designs for 
spaceships that spin while flying to cause artificial gravity, which really 
isn't gravity, just the affect of inertia.  Earth is the opposite,  the 
earth spins but everything is pulled inward.  On a spinning spaceship 
everything is pushed outward from the center."

They aren't the same thing, everything is pulled inwards on Earth because 
there's a huge ball of rock applying gravity to you. In a spinning space 
station, there's no Earth-sized ball of rock to gravitationally pull you 
in. Look up centripetal acceleration to gain a better understanding of 
these concepts.
comments.author: cuckoonest168

comments.text:
+JourneyTotheTruthandTotalRandomness  "Without gravity this pendulum and 
balloon experiment would not work" 

Why yes it would. Otherwise it would violate the equivalence principle.

"You could accelerate all you want forward in space and neither will move 
in an enclosed cylinder with air."

But it would. That's the whole idea: you can't distinguish acceleration 
from gravity without looking out the window.

"designs for spaceships that spin while flying to cause artificial gravity, 
which really isn't gravity, just the affect of inertia. "

Einstein's great insight is that all gravity is in some sense the effect of 
inertia. What it *means* to have inertia is to travel in "straight lines" 
through space. When you have a massive object like the Earth, the "straight 
lines" are really curved and the way we see this is as a force pushing us 
towards the ground. But it is an illusion, much like the spinning spaceship.

"Earth is the opposite, the earth spins but everything is pulled inward."

Because it's the mass that does it, not the centrifugal acceleration. The 
Earth's rotation does however decrease the gravitational acceleration near 
the equator, by a very small amount.

"If anyone truly understood how gravity worked then we would have it on the 
space station. "

Considering general relativity works out to astounding precision, we 
understand gravity very well. We don't know how to make a quantum theory of 
gravity, but quantum effects would be very small unless you were in an 
extreme environment like close to the singularity of a black hole or the 
early universe.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+cuckoonest168
 lol..still doesn't make sense to me.  Acceleration and gravity to me are 
two different things.  Without gravity this pendulum and balloon experiment 
would not work.  You could accelerate all you want forward in space and 
neither will move in an enclosed cylinder with air.  Now, if you're 
accelerating and an external force such as gravity is present it will work 
and you will even feel inertia.  But inertia does not need gravity to work 
hence why we have designs for spaceships that spin while flying to cause 
artificial gravity, which really isn't gravity, just the affect of 
inertia.  Earth is the opposite,  the earth spins but everything is pulled 
inward.  On a spinning spaceship everything is pushed outward from the 
center. 

If anyone truly understood how gravity worked then we would have it on the 
space station.  Everything so far is just theory.  If I think about it 
enough I may figure it out.  I mean, if I knew that buckyballs and mini 
black holes existed before I was even 10 years old before they were even 
discovered then I think I have a shot at figuring out gravity.  Don't ask 
me how I knew, the information just pops in my head from time to time which 
leads me to believe that all information past and present already exists at 
once.  But that's a whole other topic.
comments.author: JourneyTotheTruthandTotalRandomness

comments.text:
+JourneyTotheTruthandTotalRandomness That's not how you think of it. 
Instead consider the following thought experiment proposed by Einstein:

You're in a windowless spaceship accelerating upwards at 9.81 m/s^2. Is 
there any experiment you can do, short of looking outside, to determine if 
you're really in a spaceship or just in a locked room on Earth?

The answer postulated by general relativity is that there isn't. It's in 
that sense that gravity and acceleration are the same thing; both are 
"inertial" fictitious forces much like the centrifugal force you get when 
turning in a car.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+JourneyTotheTruthandTotalRandomness The Earth is traveling in space, it's 
true, and it can't be said that the Earth as a whole is not accelerating in 
some way (though it it not proposed to be so). However we're talking about 
gravity pulling you down, not pushing you out. The Earth being spherical is 
the most conservative shape because if it was all being pulled in equally 
from all sides then there would not be any flat surfaces; hence it being 
round.

So a child (including me and you two guys :) ) is born with strong tendency 
to be religious or being atheist as a predisposition of the DNA code and 
their brains. Just to give example Richard Dawkins underwent testing (as a 
part of mentioned research) and was shown to have extremely low activity in 
temporal lobes, thus his strong position on atheism very well could be a 
natural consequence coming from his DNA. As a side note brain of course 
does not carry information which religion person will choose, this is 100% 
learned.

I do not have the sources for this but you can easily Google it, it is 
serious research that sprouted from research on epilepsy (since originally 
it was observed that epileptics have statistically significantly higher 
chances of being religious) .
comments.author: Josef Habdank

comments.text:

makes no sense".

It's a lot like saying "I hate ice cream because I tried cherry flavoured 
ice cream and didn't like it."

Being atheist is the default position for each newborn. It's religion

some don't. Both kind can read the bible and either 1) get disappointed 
(become atheists - again) 2) not get excited (staying atheists).
This holds up in any country, with any religion, any books.
Crhistianity takes no advantage.

bottom line: nobody thinks that Andersen's stories are true as per

for all people who get offended by what I just wrote: just please remain
